h3. Issue Summary

Page PDF export size significantly increases if page consist of .jpeg/jpg images
h3. Environment

Confluence 7.0.1, 6.15.9
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Prepare  .jpeg and .png files. Note the size of both files.
 # Create two Confluence pages. Add .jpeg image to the page A and .png attachment to page B
 # Export both pages to PDF
 # Check the size of generated PDF export files

h3. Expected Results

Size of PDF export is similar to the size of the images (or smaller due to the compression)
h3. Actual Results
 * PDF export from page A with .jpeg attachment (85KB) is 422kb
 * PDF export from page B with .png attachment (355KB) is 180kb

h3. Notes
 * For jpeg attachment (3.2mb) page pdf export increases to 17mb
 * Adding multiple jpeg attachments multiplies the increase in PDF export size

h3. Workaround

We found a 2 steps workaround which consists of:
 * Using the *Export to Word* feature to get the Confluence page saved as a *doc* file first
 * Then, open the *doc* file in Microsoft Word, go to *File > Print* and select the *Microsoft Print to PDF* in the printer dropdown list to save the .doc file to a .pdf file.
fields.summary: Page PDF export size significantly increases if page consist of .jpeg/jpg images

h3. Issue Summary
Bug raised in Devhelp: https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/DEVHELP-3241
{quote}
Hi,

I have explained more here: https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/transactions-in-activeobjects-upgrade-tasks/29700/2

Basically, the Data Center verification requires that we ensure we don't have "big" Hibernate sessions in upgrade tasks, when we go over thousands of objects. They tell us to flush the session and commit the transaction regularly. But Atlassian doesn't provide any way to do that, unless I'm mistaken. 

To reproduce the test, use the code in the 1st answer of the CDAC post.

Our product is not impacted yet because we've never had to perform a large upgrade task, but we need to be ready for the next time we need to update our data.
{quote}

h3. Expected Results
Provide a way to create isolated/REQUIRES_NEW transactions

h3. Actual Results
With the current proposed solution (which itself uses the non-recommended API ComponentManager.getInstance()): "IllegalStateException: Transaction already active"

h3. Workaround

Try to get a reference to the existing hibernate session (created by the parent) and then calling clear() and/or flush() on it, but we never tried this and I don’t know if we’d have run into the same problems with the unavailable OSGi packages that you noted.
fields.summary: Hibernate Sessions can't be fully flushed in upgrade tasks

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Download sample app: [^conf-transformer-test.zip]
 # Run "atlas-clean && atlas-run -v 6.12.0 --data-version 6.12.0" in conf-transformer-test folder
 # In Demonstration space:
 # Go to Space tools -> Content tools -> Export
 # Select PDF
 # Select type (I've tried both Normal and Custom)
 # Notice "Found 1 pages" in log and debugger for each page in PDF
 # Create DEV space with 4 pages (3 siblings and 1 child page)
 # Follow the same steps as for DS and get the same result

h3. Expected Results

ConversionContext.getContentTree returns a object containing all pages to be included in export
h3. Actual Results

ConversionContext.getContentTree returns an object containing only current page
h3. Notes
 * API returns expected number of pages when command is {{atlas-clean && atlas-debug -version 6.11.0}} or {{6.12.0}}
 * From server ecosystem team: "--data-version should match --version unless one might want to test for an upgrade path from an older database version. In some cases not setting --data-version and setting --version  can have undesired results because it may try and set --data-version to latest and that could be a cloud version though it's unlikely"

h3. Impact
 * From vendor:
{quote}My add-ons provide special behavior when multiple pages are exported in one PDF. Unfortunately this is no longer possible in Confluence 6.13 because of ConversionContext.getContentTree now only returns the current page, not the list of all pages included in the PDF. There doesn't appear to be any other way to get this information.

This change means that my users will lose a useful feature.
{quote}
 * Vendor has *_1.5k_* customer installs potentially affected by this
 * This has not been tested on prod instance

h3. Workaround

Use {{atlas-clean && atlas-debug -version 6.11.0}} or {{6.12.0}} when debugging

h2. Issue Summary
Confluence provides one with the ability of checking who are the administrators of a given Space by going to Space Tools -> Overview and checking the names right next to the line that says *Administrators*. If this given Space has too many Administrators, the list may be collapsed and an ellipsis button may appear at the end of the line for one to expand and see the full list. Confluence can hit 100% of CPU usage {color:red}and may go down{color} depending on the size of the full list.

h2. Steps to Reproduce
This can be easily reproduced by adding a group with multiple users as Space Admin. It is unknown how many users would be necessary to trigger this behaviour, however, it has been observed that an instance with 14.000 users within a group ran into this problem when this group was added as Space Admin.
# Ensure that you have a group with a few thousand users at least on it.
# As an administrator, click on the Cog Icon in your right upper corner and then click on General Configuration.
# Look for Space Permissions.
# Select a space and click on Manage Permissions.
# A list of groups and users will appear. Click on Edit Permissions nearby the group list.
# Look for the group with multiple users and check the Admin checkbox under the Space column.
# Save the changes.
# Now, go to that Space, click on Space Tools and then click on Overview.
# Click on the Ellipsis button right next to the Administrators line.
# At this point, CPU usage will increase and the application may get stuck forever running the following endpoint:
{code}
/spaces/viewspacesummary.action?key=SPAC&showAllAdmins=true
{code}

h2. Expected Results
Instead of crashing, the application should either display a list of Administrator or a message saying that the list is too long to be rendered.

h2. Actual Results
CPU goes wild, the list is never rendered and the application most than likely needs to be restarted to get functional once again.

h2. Notes
Ideally, the application should avoid rendering huge lists or there should have been a pagination mechanism to avoid this problem from happening.

h2. Workaround
Avoid using groups as Space Administrators unless these groups have a small list of users within them.

h2. Extra - Technical Notes - AKA What Happens in the Backend
First, Confluence will grab a list of everyone that has Administrator Permissions for that space - This include user IDs and group IDs:
{code:sql}
select permission0_.SPACEID as SPACEID2_52_0_, permission0_.PERMID as PERMID1_52_0_, permission0_.PERMID 
as PERMID1_52_1_, permission0_.SPACEID as SPACEID2_52_1_, permission0_.PERMTYPE as PERMTYPE3_52_1_, permission0_.PERMGROUPNAME 
as PERMGROU4_52_1_, permission0_.PERMUSERNAME as PERMUSER5_52_1_, permission0_.PERMALLUSERSSUBJECT as PERMALLU6_52_1_, permission0_.CREATOR 
as CREATOR7_52_1_, permission0_.CREATIONDATE as CREATION8_52_1_, permission0_.LASTMODIFIER as LASTMODI9_52_1_, permission0_.LASTMODDATE 
as LASTMOD10_52_1_ from SPACEPERMISSIONS permission0_ where permission0_.SPACEID='SPACE_ID_HERE';
{code}

Once that's done, the user IDs and group IDs will be used to create a list with actual names so one knows who the administrators really are:
{code:sql}
select internalus1_.user_name as col_0_0_ from cwd_membership hibernatem0_ cross join cwd_user internalus1_ cross join cwd_group internalgr2_ 
where hibernatem0_.child_user_id=internalus1_.id and hibernatem0_.parent_id=internalgr2_.id and (hibernatem0_.child_group_id is null) 
and internalgr2_.lower_group_name='GROUPS_AND_USERS_FROM_STEP_1' and internalgr2_.directory_id='DIRECTORY_ID_FROM_STEP_1' order by internalus1_.lower_user_name;
{code}

With the results of the second query, the list is rendered. However, if the second query returns multiple results, such as thousands of users, Confluence will attempt to render a list with all of these names, which crashes the application.
fields.summary: To Display all Space Administrators on Space Tools can bring Confluence down

h3. Summary

PDF export can cause Out Of Memory if the page contains a long indented/nested numbered list.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a page
# Edit the storage format with Source Editor and add the contents of this file:
#*  [^longindentedlist] 
(!) This is a long indented numbered list, eg:
{code}
1.
    a.
2.
    a.
    b.
    ...
{code}
# Export the page to PDF

h3. Expected Results

The export completes.

h3. Actual Results
This can be seen in the atlassian-confluence.log file on a server instance:
{code}
2019-09-05 15:53:42,721 WARN [alert-dispatch:thread-1] [confluence.alert-log] log 1567709622608 ; WARNING ; JVM ; JVM-1002 ; Garbage collection exceeded time limit ; not-detected ;  ;  ; {"durationInMillis":5057,"windowInMillis":20000,"limitPercent":10,"threadMemoryAllocations":"","threadDump":[]}
{code}

This can be seen in catalina.out:
{code}
05-Sep-2019 15:35:02.592 INFO [http-nio-8090-exec-4] com.sun.jersey.server.impl.application.WebApplicationImpl._initiate Initiating Jersey application, version 'Jersey: 1.19.4 05/24/2017 03:20 PM'
Exception in thread "http-nio-8090-exec-5" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
    at java.util.Arrays.copyOf(Arrays.java:3332)
    at java.lang.AbstractStringBuilder.ensureCapacityInternal(AbstractStringBuilder.java:124)
    at java.lang.AbstractStringBuilder.append(AbstractStringBuilder.java:674)
    at java.lang.StringBuffer.append(StringBuffer.java:388)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.css.newmatch.Matcher$Mapper.mapChild(Matcher.java:386)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.css.newmatch.Matcher.matchElement(Matcher.java:154)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.css.newmatch.Matcher.getMapper(Matcher.java:236)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.css.newmatch.Matcher.getCascadedStyle(Matcher.java:86)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.context.StyleReference.getCascadedStyle(StyleReference.java:204)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.layout.SharedContext.getStyle(SharedContext.java:573)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.layout.SharedContext.getStyle(SharedContext.java:552)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.layout.BoxBuilder.createChildren(BoxBuilder.java:1096)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.layout.BoxBuilder.createChildren(BoxBuilder.java:116)
    at org.xhtmlrenderer.render.BlockBox.ensureChildren(BlockBox.java:947)
{code}

Notice that the renderer is in the process of parsing the numbered list based on the stack above (*ensureChildren* and *createChildren* methods).

(!) On a Data Center instance, the sandbox crashes while creating the export even if you increase its heap size significantly.
 
h3. Notes

This *problem does not affect versions below 6.13*, which indicates it is related to the bug fix below:

* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-54773

In 6.12 and earlier versions, the renderer does not identify the indented list and builds it as a normal numbered list, example:
# The following list in the Confluence page:
{code}
1.
    a.
2.
    a.
    b.
    ...
{code}
# Becomes this in the exported PDF:
{code}
1.
    1.
2.
    1.
    2.
    ...
{code}

The export tool is now able to identify the indented list and render it. However, the side effect is that it may OOM if the list is too long.

h3. Workaround

Remove the indented numbered list from the page or turn it into a normal numbered list (not indented) before exporting.
fields.summary: PDF export causes out of memory due to long indented numbered list in the page

 * You have a very populated Confluence instance
 * You are migrating a space from your existing Confluence instance to a new one
 * You want to make sure you have installed on the new instance all the *macros/plugins* the migrated space needs to work properly
 * You are able to consult the *Macro Usage* page, where the used macros are listed. The pages where they are being used are also listed.
 * You would like to generate a report of all the macros/plugins *used* by a space that are currently *missing* from the system

When a page uses *macros/plugins* that are disabled or not installed on the instance, the only indication of that is the *Unknown Macro* message displayed on that page.

On very populated spaces or sites, it may take a long time before noticing the missing any *macros/plugins* on the pages.
h3. Suggested Solution

The *Macro Usage* page can include a list of pages with missing *macros/plugins*. Identifying their spaces would be a plus.
h3. Workaround

Searching page by page for missing *macros/plugins*.

h3. Problem Definition
An [User Macro|https://confluence.atlassian.com/conf613/writing-user-macros-964961202.html] is a great way to extend Confluence functionalities, since the administrator can code virtually anything.

Depending on what the macro is coded for, its operation may take a long time to complete and, while it is running, it is prone to impact on Confluence performance.
Currently, there's no mechanism to kill the inner operation performed by the user macro if it is running for longer than a threshold.

h3. Suggested Solution
Introduce a configurable timeout to user macros and an option to asynchronously run them.
If a macro is taking a long time to complete, kill the macro rendering thread after the specified threshold.

Although the macro should be extensively tested for performance and security reasons, it would be great if Confluence could safeguard itself from expensive operations.
 
h3. Workaround 
_No workaround so far.
fields.summary: As a Confluence administrator I would like to configure a timeout specific to long running user macros

h3. Issue Summary
Members of the {{confluence-administrators}} group are treated as a _special user_ in Confluence as described in [Global Permissions Overview|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/global-permissions-overview-138709.html#GlobalPermissionsOverview-Comparingtheconfluence-administratorsgroupwiththeadministratorpermissions].
This documentation states that members of that group would still consider the [Space Permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/space-permissions-overview-139521.html] and [Page Restrictions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/page-restrictions-139414.html] when editing a page. However, there's no reference whatsoever to creating a new page, which uses the same permission on the Space level.
The problem is that even when the _Add pages_ space permission is revoked from all groups and users within a Space, members of the {{confluence-administrators}} can still create a page in that Space, while editing an existing page isn't possible.
It would be expected that consistency occurs among the same space permission, preventing members of the {{confluence-administrators}} from creating pages in the above situation.

h3. Environment
* This was validated on Confluence Server 6.13.4 and 6.15.4.
* It is expected this bug affects any version prior to, and including, 6.15.X.
* This also affects Confluence Data Center deployments.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install a vanilla instance of Confluence.
# Create a sample Space.
# Logged with an user part of the {{confluence-administrators}} group, edit the permissions of this Space.
 #* Make sure only the {{confluence-users}} group has permissions assigned, removing any other group and users.
 #* Make sure only the _View_ and the _Space Admin_ permissions are assigned to the {{confluence-users}} group.
# Go back to the Home Page of the target space and note that the _Edit_ button in that page is gone.
# Click on the _Create blank page_ button.

h3. Expected Results
Confluence doesn't allow a page to be created in the current Space, since the _Add Page_ Space permission was revoked from all groups and users in that Space.

h3. Actual Results
Confluence still allows users of the {{confluence-administrators}} group to create a page.

h3. Notes
If trying to create a page using a template other than the blank page, for example the _How-to article_ template, the admin is able to navigate through the template form, but creating the page fails with a _Not Permitted_ error page as the image below.
 !create-from-template-img001.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
_Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available._
fields.summary: Revoking the Add Page Space permission from all groups and users in a specific Space still allows confluence-administrators to create a new blank page in that Space

After upgrade Confluence from 6.15.4 to 7.0.1, some sites are prompted with a CVE warning. Upon review, the CVE details clearly indicate that 7.0.1 and higher are not affected and in turn this notification does not apply.

  # Wait a few days to allow Confluence to check in the SEN with the older, vulnerable version of Confluence.

h3. Problem Definition
When users are [disabled|https://confluence.atlassian.com/conf613/delete-or-disable-users-964961157.html] in the Confluence user directory we are unable to search them because they are not active in the Lucene index.
Because of this, I am unable to create a [task report macro|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/add-assign-and-view-tasks-590260030.html] targeting disabled users, since they won't appear in the _Assigned to_ search box when configuring the macro.

h3. Suggested Solution
Make it possible to search for disabled users when configuring the task report macro.
 
h3. Workaround 
The workaround below is valid if you need to have a page with a task report macro targeting a disabled user.

# Install a Source Editor App available in the Marketplace.
 #* Suggested Apps are [Confluence Source Editor|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1210722/confluence-source-editor?hosting=server&tab=overview] (unsupported) or [Source Editor for Confluence|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1215664/source-editor-for-confluence?hosting=server&tab=overview] (supported by _[Mohami|https://mohamicorp.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DOC/pages/1966116/Source+Editor+for+Confluence]_).
# In the Confluence database, get the {{user_key}} of the target user -- this key will be used later.
{code}
select user_key
from user_mapping
where username='<target username>'
;
{code}
# In a Confluence page, add a task report macro and configure it targeting any sample, active user.
# Edit the same page and now use one of the Source Editor Apps to configure the source of the page.
# Search for the macro definition, which might be similar to the below.
{code}
  <ac:structured-macro ac:macro-id="66f9a8c1-6618-4a87-ad65-b814a0d17a82" ac:name="tasks-report-macro" ac:schema-version="1">
    <ac:parameter ac:name="spaces">SPACE002</ac:parameter>
    <ac:parameter ac:name="assignees">
      <ri:user ri:userkey="4028808d6d1bacb9016d1bb051830001"/>
    </ac:parameter>
  </ac:structured-macro>
{code}
# Where you see {{<ri:user ri:userkey="<sample user key>"/>}}, change the key with the one you retrieved from the database and apply the changes to the page.
 #* If you want to add more users, simply add more {{<ri:user ri:userkey="<sample user key>"/>}} tags inside the {{<ac:parameter ac:name="assignees">}}.


If you want a list of pages with tasks assigned to a target user, without the need to have a task report macro, you may rely on a REST API call as below.
You may run this API as a Confluence user, instead of an admin, but you may not have access to all pages on which the target user had tasks assigned.
{code}
CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL=<Confluence Base URL>
ADMIN_USERNAME=<Confluence admin username>
ADMIN_PASSWORD=<Confluence admin password>
TARGET_USERNAME=<target username>
NUM_TASKS=<max number of tasks in the list>

curl -u ${ADMIN_USERNAME}:${ADMIN_PASSWORD} -H 'Accept: application/json' ${CONFLUENCE_BASE_URL}'/rest/inlinetasks/1/task-report/?pageIndex=0&pageSize='${NUM_TASKS}'&reportParameters=%7B%22columns%22%3A%5B%22description%22%2C%22duedate%22%2C%22assignee%22%2C%22location%22%5D%2C%22spaces%22%3A%5B%5D%2C%22pages%22%3A%5B%5D%2C%22duedateFrom%22%3Anull%2C%22duedateTo%22%3Anull%2C%22createdateFrom%22%3Anull%2C%22createdateTo%22%3Anull%2C%22assignees%22%3A%5B%22'${TARGET_USERNAME}'%22%5D%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%5D%2C%22status%22%3Anull%2C%22labels%22%3A%5B%5D%2C%22pageSize%22%3A20%2C%22sortColumn%22%3A%22assignee%22%2C%22reverseSort%22%3Afalse%7D'

fields.description:
As a +system admin+ 
 I want to +have a way to change pages owners (author, last modifier) during a Space import operation+
 So that +If I receive an exported space in XML format, I can easily do a "from-to" operation to assign pages to new owners+
h4. Suggestion Summary
 - Customer company A is bought by company B.
 - Both have Confluence, Directories are not integrated
 - Sysadmins on company B create users for employees from company A, but they do not always match the ones they had in A (such as, A is johnsmith, B is jsmith)
 - Customer would rather have pages assigned correctly, than listing _unknown user johnsmith_

h4. Proposed Solution

Import operation could allow admins to input a from-to CSV file indicating old user names and new ones, to prevent that issue.
h4. Possible Workarounds
 - Have the space imported in a non-production instance and run the procedures from:
 [How To - Transfer Content Ownership in between Users|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-transfer-content-ownership-in-between-users-958450595.html]
 - Try find-and-replace operations on the XML file such as

{code:java|title=Replace Name}
sed -i.tmp 's@<property name="name"><!\[CDATA\[oldusername\]\]></property>@<property name="name"><!\[CDATA\[newusername\]\]></property>@g' entities.xml
{code}
{code:java|title=Replace Lower Name}
sed -i.tmp 's@<property name="lowerName"><!\[CDATA\[oldusername\]\]></property>@<property name="lowerName"><!\[CDATA\[newusername\]\]></property>@g' entities.xml
{code}
Again, we must be mindful about the space name. I don't think you gonna have spaces with usernames on it, but, just in case, be mindful about that. If that happens, after you have SED'ed your way, open the entities.xml file and look for the tag below:
{code:java}
 <object class="Space" package="com.atlassian.confluence.spaces">
 <id name="id">3440641</id>
 <property name="name"><![CDATA[OldUserName]]></property>
 <property name="key"><![CDATA[MAR]]></property>
 <property name="lowerKey"><![CDATA[mar]]></property>
{code}
Once you found it, just replace the name accordingly to respect the previous space name and save the file. Then follow the steps previously outlined here and we should be fine.
fields.summary: Bulk change ownership during XML Space Import

h3. Issue Summary Whitespace added after a table within a bullet list or numbered list is removed when the page is published or previewed h3. Environment Observed in Confluence 6.6.16 and reproduced with Confluence 6.15.8 h3. Steps to Reproduce # Create a numbered or bulleted list # After a few points, insert a table # Add another point after the table # Attempt to add white space after the table by pressing enter (or shift-enter, a common Atlassian community suggestion) or enter and a few spaces. The editor shows white space added between the table and the next item in the list. # 'Preview' or 'Publish the page. The white space is not displayed. h3. Expected Results What is displayed in the editor should remain in the preview/published version. 1. Item 1 2. Item 2 with table ||Heading 1||Heading 2|| |Col A1|Col A2| \\ \\ 3. Item 3 h3. Actual Results The list shows no white space after the table. 1. Item 1 2. Item 2 with table ||Heading 1||Heading 2|| |Col A1|Col A2| 3. Item 3 h3. Notes * Similar to [CONFSERVER-58404 : White space is removed between code block macros|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-58404] * Setting frontend.editor.v4.disable in darkfeatures.action doesn't help h3. Workaround Four workarounds have been tested, although they are admittedly clunky. +Workaround #1+: 1. After adding/editing the table, press ENTER. This creates a new bullet point below. 2. Press backspace (this deletes the bullet point) 3. Press the space bar twice. 4. Click 'publish' or 'preview'. The single line of white space is preserved. +Workaround #2+: 1. Insert a 'section' macro underneath the table. This appears in the editor but shows as white space in preview (or published version). +Workaround #3+: 1. Use the source editor to add html after the table: & nbsp;
2. Publish the page +Workaround #4+: 1. Click "+" (insert more content) and select 'Markup' 2. Insert markup "\\ \\"and press 'preview' or 'publish'

Currently the following document mentions that users in Confluence can create spaces using existing templates.
* [Create a Space From a Template|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/create-a-space-from-a-template-829076185.html]

One of these templates is Software Project space template. The documentation above does not specify any limitation on who can create this space in Confluence. h3. Issue Summary
 * Backslash ( \ ) characters in page names cause the PDF page exports to fail with 'HTTP Status 400 - Bad Request', due to the PDF file naming conventions
 * Problem only affects Data Center installations
 * The PDF is actually created in <confluence_home>/temp/ but is not presented to the user ('HTTP Status 400' occurs)

h3. Environment

Confluence 6.12.x Data Center and onwards

Server versions are unaffected.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install & login to Confluence Data Center (Any version from 6.12 onwards)
 # Create a page with a backslash character in the page name
 # Click the ellipsis (...) and choose 'Export to PDF'

h3. Expected Results

The page should be converted to PDF and the PDF download presented to the user.
h3. Actual Results

The PDF is generated in <confluence_home>/temp/ but the browser will display HTTP Status 400.  

 
{code:java}
HTTP Status 400 – Bad Request
Type          Status Report
Message       Invalid URI
Description   The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed request syntax, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing).Apache Tomcat/9.0.22
{code}
 
h3. Notes
 * In Confluence Server, the filename format is
{noformat}
<spacekey>-<pagename_minus_spaces>-ddmmyy-hhmm-*.pdf
{noformat}
However, if special characters exist in the page name (such as %, \, /, $, &, %, :, ?) the PDF filename format changes to:
{noformat}
<spacekey>-<pageid>-ddmmyy-hhmm-*.pdf{noformat}

 * In Confluence Data Center, this also appears to be true, but the expected naming for special page name characters changes from Confluence Data Center 6.12 onwards due to a change in Confluence 6.12 DC where PDF exports now get handled by the external process pool (sandbox).  [6.12 Release Notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/confluence-6-12-release-notes-957143056.html] have further details.

h3. Workaround

There are currently 2 ways to workaround this problem:

+Workaround #1+:
 # Change the backslash () in the page name to another character (eg. / )

+_or_+

+Workaround #2:+
 # Disable the PDF export sandbox with the following CATALINA_OPTS in setenv.sh on each node in the cluster: 
{code:java}
 CATALINA_OPTS="-Dpdf.export.sandbox.disable=true ${CATALINA_OPTS}"{code}
# Perform a rolling restart of each node for the change to take effect.  

(!) Note: This has the potential to cause extra heap usage within the JVM, as it brings PDF export operations back into the main heap space rather than running it externally.
fields.summary: Exporting pages to PDF with a backslash in the page name causes a HTTP Status 400 error

h3. Problem Definition
When migrating Confluence Spaces from one instance to another, users may still access pages in the legacy instance without knowing the content was migrated and a more recent version is available.
Users may be directed to the legacy instance because of bookmarks or links available in external systems (not Confluence).
It would be interesting if we could adjust a rewrite rule directly in Confluence configuration to send users to the new instance when they are trying to read content from migrated Spaces.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide the ability to configure directly in Confluence rewrite rules based on Spaces (Space key, for example) to send users to a new Confluence instance.
 
h3. Workaround 
Review the options highlighted in [How to redirect Confluence users to a new URL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-redirect-confluence-users-to-a-new-url-976758203.html]

h3. Issue Summary

Confluence allows you to create a blogpost with duplicate titles if the *Posting Date* of the blogs are different.

However, if you create a new blogpost with today's date as the *Posting Date* and using an existing blogpost's title, it will fail due to this error.

!CONFSERVER-58789 Error.png|thumbnail!

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create one blogpost titled '*ABC*' and set the *Posting Date* to a date in the past (e.g. Aug 8, 2019).
 # Create a second blogpost titled '*ABC*' as well, and don't alter the *Posting Date*. Let it remain as today's date (e.g. Aug 29, 2019).
 # Publish the blog.

h3. Expected Results

The blogpost should be created.
h3. Actual Results

The blogpost fails to be created with this error appearing in the editor:
{quote}A page with the title 'ABC' already exists in this space. Enter a different title for your page.
{quote}
h3. Workaround

After you receive the error message, click on the *Posting Date* at the bottom of the page and *don't make any changes*. Just close the pop-up by clicking into the editor's body and publish the blog. It will be successfully created.
